awd_titl_txt: NeTS: Medium: Collaborative Research: Detecting and Localizing Spectrum Offenders Using Crowdsourcing
awd_abstract_narration:
Software defined radio (SDR) is emerging as a key technology to satisfy rapidly increasing data rate demands on the nation's mobile wireless networks while ensuring coexistence with other spectrum users.  When SDRs are in the hands and pockets of average people, it will be easy for a selfish user to alter his device to transmit and receive data on unauthorized spectrum, or ignore priority rules, making the network less reliable for many other users.  Further, malware could cause an SDR to exhibit illegal spectrum use without the user's awareness.  The FCC has an enforcement bureau which detects interference via complaints and extensive manual investigation. The mechanisms used currently for locating spectrum offenders are time consuming, human-intensive, and expensive.  A violator's illegal spectrum use can be too temporary or too mobile to be detected and located using existing processes.  This project envisions a future where a crowdsourced and networked fleet of spectrum sensors deployed in homes, community and office buildings, on vehicles, and in cell phones will detect, identify, and locate illegal use of the spectrum across a wide areas and frequency bands. This project will investigate and test new privacy-preserving crowdsourcing methods to detect and locate spectrum offenders.  New tools to quickly find offenders will discourage users from illegal SDR activity, and enable recovery from spectrum-offending malware.  In short, these tools will ensure the efficient, reliable, and fair use of the spectrum for network operators, government and scientific purposes, and wireless users.  New course materials and demonstrations for use in public outreach will be developed on the topics of wireless communications, dynamic spectrum access, data mining, network security, and crowdsourcing.

There are several challenges the project will address in the development of  methods and tools to find spectrum offenders.  First, the project will enable localization of offenders via crowdsourced spectrum measurements that do not decode the transmitted data and thus preserve users' data and identity privacy.  Second, the crowd-sourced sensing strategy will implicitly adapt to the density of traffic and explicitly adapt to focus on suspicious activity.  Next, the sensing strategy will stay within an energy budget, and have incentive models to encourage participation, yet have sufficient spatial and temporal coverage to provide high statistical confidence in detecting illegal activity.  Finally, the developed methods will be evaluated using both simulation and extensive experiments, to quantify performance and provide a rich public data set for other researchers.

por.por_cntn:
This project made the following contributions towards developing methods and systems to detect and localize spectrum offenders using crowdsourcing [Project webpage - http://ansr.cs.utah.edu/spectrum-offenders/].

First, it developed novel methods for transmitter localization in a crowdsourced environment where both the transmitter and the receivers are mobile. Significantly, these methods can localize multiple nodes that are transmitting simultaneously. Furthermore, these methods use both physics-based and data-oriented learning approaches in a variety of indoor and outdoor settings. The learning-based approaches not only better capture the peculiarities of the radio frequency (RF) environment but also overcome challenges due to both transmitter and receivers being mobile, sparsity of training data, and transmit power variability. For assistance with implementation, data collection, and experimental evaluation pertaining to this project, a new untethered, software defined radio (SDR), that can be carried in pockets, has been designed and built, and used for RF sensing. This SDR can be controlled by a mobile device including a tablet or a smartphone over Bluetooth. This project has collected and used a variety of datasets to evaluate the different localization approaches and shown that the new approaches are robust and reduce localization errors in comparison to existing work. A game-theoretic approach to select crowdsourced mobile users was also developed to maximize coverage but minimize the total payoff considering both the budget limit and mobility of crowdsourced users.

Second, this project also developed new approaches for location privacy of receivers participating in crowdsourced localization. One of its novel approaches, called the “adjusted measurement approach” generates pseudo-locations for participating receivers and report these pseudo-locations along with adjusted received signal strength (RSS) measurements as if the measurements were made at the pseudo-locations. The RSS values are adjusted by representing those as a weighted linear combination of the RSS values at the receivers, where receivers closer to the false location have a higher weight than those far away. Evaluations using an indoor dataset and an outdoor RSS dataset from Phoenix, AZ, show that this approach reduces the error in localizing transmitters from data from crowdsourced receivers in comparison to those approaches that just add noise to receiver locations, while preserving location privacy.

Third, the project developed novel methods, and systems for detecting and analyzing RF signals in real-time using both supervised and unsupervised learning approaches. Notably, a novel Environmental Sensing Capability (ESC) sensor for the CBRS band has been built using deep learning concepts on a commercially available SDR. The ESC implementation can detect five types of naval radar signals with more than 99% accuracy when the peak-to-average SNR (with receiver noise) or SIR (with AWGN) is above 20 dB. This implementation meets the performance requirements for NTIA ESC certification. In the presence of real, unpredictable, LTE interference, this ESC implementation can detect radar types 2-5 with accuracy of more than 99% and for radar type 1, the detection accuracy is 98.5%.

Fourth, the project also focused on improved scalability and modeling for spatial scan statistics; these statistics identify spatial regions of potentially nefarious activity by comparing a measured signal against a known expected background distribution.  Among other improvements, this project developed two new key modeling extensions.  It allowed for the objects causing signals to be spatial trajectories (e.g., rogue devices moving through a crowd) instead of only fixed-point objects.  Furthermore, it developed the ability to use spatial models where the signal strength decays with measurements further from the source; previous approaches required regions where an object has the same effect within a threshold distance, no matter how close it is to the source.  
 
These methods and systems developed in this project have been reported through several papers and articles in some of the top publication venues and are available for broader community use. The pocket-SDR built in this project can be used for applications other than localization due to its rapid data gathering capability.  The project team has integrated elements of spatial scan statistics into the open source python library developed by them, called pyscan: https://mmath.dev/pyscan/. This project allowed University of Utah to build a strong research collaboration with the Idaho National Laboratory and Nokia Bell Labs that resulted in several joint publications and system development projects. Over 20 students, including both graduate and undergraduate students, many from diverse and underrepresented groups, participated and contributed to the project, resulting in several PhD dissertations and MS theses, and one BS thesis. The project also contributed to demos and code and a tutorial tied to spectrum measurements and localization of a jammer on the POWDER platform. The project also created tutorials on spectrum license lookup, channel path loss modeling, and RSS measurements. This project contributed a unique dataset of RSS measurements in a 4 square km area on POWDER. The research performed under this project has been included in the curriculum at the PI institutions.
